author: Chalk
title: Stroke victim
body:
Admitted to Bradford Royal Infirmary ward 6 after having a stroke.  
Appreciate things difficult due to covid and nobody is allowed to visit so worrying times for families as we can only go by what we are being told.  
Please do not take what they tell you for granted ask questions and keep asking.  
We have receive that many conflicting tales from doctors, nurses, therapist and SS I sometimes wonder if thay are talking about the same person.  
At this present time we have been told she will be coming home on Friday the ward no nothing about it, therapist were suppose to be introducing new foods over a week ago looks like that's not happened,  
and the list goes on  
At this moment in time we dont know who to believe its appalling firstly for the patients ,seems there just getting basic care and not the care they are entitled to and for the families who have to go through all the upset

readBy.name: Bradford Teaching Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust

author: ulsterwolf
title: Covid19 vaccination
body:
I received a text on my mobile phone and was booked in for a vaccination on Monday at 1130.  
From the security at the car park all the way through to the admin staff and nursing staff I had such a positive experience!  
every single person was very helpful and the whole operation was planned and ran to perfection.  
I realise that experiences like this never reach the news or press as they seem to concentrate on only the negative aspects of the pandemic, but every single person involved was a credit to the NHS. Please convey my thanks to them all for such a positive experience! !  
Many thanks to you all

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: angel27
title: Doncaster Social Prescribing helps me and the people I talk to
body:
My domestic abuse support worker suggested I volunteer as a Social Prescription volunteer because my experience of abuse, cancer and my own loss of my son is really relevant to lots of women and I could help them. I can help them because I have worked through in counselling my own abusive marriage and my loss of my son and how desperate I was after he died and how I tried things to forget.  
My support worker put me in touch with Lauren from the the Social Prescribing service and I volunteered and after my police check came through I was asked to visit one person. This was last March and Covid was stopping visiting. I started by phoning this lady once a week who was lonely and has health issues. Its about listening and I know if I have any concerns I can take these to Lauren as the Coordinator.  
This helps me too because I enjoy being able to help them through things I know about and can point them to services and help and I get a sense of satisfaction in supporting them. This work also means I am not just looking at my own situation. This gives them a human contact which is really important to them and helps against the loneliness when they don't meet anyone because of Covid.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
University of Stirling, Faculty of Social Sciences

author: #NotGoodEnough
title: Terrible care of relative in ward 5
body:
I don’t know where to start in my review of the terrible care my relative received. During our time on the ward visiting (end of life allowances for visiting) we witnessed poor hygiene/infection control measures on the ward. The bin in his room was literally spilling out all over the floor. In any ward this is disgusting, let alone in a covid ward. I note this is an area the hospital has already been pulled up on in inspections.  
The quiet room was unclean. In the 2 days we spent on the ward, it was never cleaned. There were dirty, used mugs and half-eaten biscuits on the table (infection control on a covid ward?!) The bed was on its side and there were pictures all over the floor. It was offered as a breathing space for us. Our relative was blind. We were told that he couldn’t have a TV on in his room because it wasn’t working. As soon as we arrived, we put the TV on. It was working. Nobody had checked. My blind relative was sat in a room with no TV because nobody had checked. When we initially asked about the TV, we reiterated that our relative was blind. The staff response was, ‘They’re all blind in here.’ Our relative had limited capacity. This issue was addressed at admission and communicated with several staff. However, upon his death, we received a call from someone who wanted to speak to him to discuss the clinical trial he was participating it. We are disgusted that proper consent was not obtained. We have received an apology for this but it is terrible practice and is a complete disgrace. We were told we would be notified of any changes in his care. We weren’t. He was put on oxygen and none of us knew. We spent HOURS trying to get through to the ward to no avail. Having been told we would be contacted we took some comfort knowing that if anything big happened, we would be informed. A DNR was also put in place without discussion with family. Upon calling the ward, we were asked to wait whilst the staff member checked on our relative to report back on how he was. We overheard staff discussing how pointless the meeting they had to attend was and how it was a waste of time. We were told initially that staff would help him mobilise to his chair because his mobility was the biggest concern we (and medical staff) had at the time. In his first few days on the ward, he wasn’t moved/helped to his chair. When asked why this was we were told there were no staff so he had to lie in bed all day. When we arrived, we were shocked at his appearance. His medical notes from that morning detailed that he was ‘bright.’ There was nothing bright about his condition. The room was freezing. Staff apologised and told us they had complained about the temperature of the room on every shift they had been on because it was harmful for the health of patients. Regardless of this, he had ONE thin bed sheet on him and was very cold. His inner mouth had medication stuck to his skin. No effort had been made to check he had swallowed his tablets. He hadn’t been given any oral care due to the condition of his mouth/tongue (which improved within hours of us being there and caring for him.) We were promised we could see him on FaceTime calls but this didn’t happen because the iPad apparently wasn’t working (although, given the ‘broken TV’ we have little faith in anything we were told.) We raised concerns with a consultant who promised to call us back. It never happened. We asked what he had eaten. Nobody knew for 48 hrs. We asked for a fluid/food chart to be started because it was apparent that nobody was monitoring him. Given his diabetes, we were horrified to learn this. When we arrived at the ward, we had a discussion with a nurse. They were, without question, the most patronising person any of us have ever met. One of my relatives was crying, watching her husband die and the nurse was jovially discussing how much they loved being in a ward because they could shave them and bath them like they used to in their early days. What that had to do with us, none of us could fathom. Even more disgustingly, we arrived to see him after he had been in hospital for over a week and we were asked what he liked to be called. He was now completely unresponsive and they had only just asked this? No ‘About Me’ was completed. Nobody bothered to check his capacity issues, despite consistently telling us he was confused. When we finally said he had to come home to die, palliative care told us that the care he had received was unacceptable. The nurses told us it was unacceptable. The doctors told us it was unacceptable. The healthcare workers told us it was unacceptable. Upon leaving, a staff member on the ward told us we had better be careful not to end up in the papers for taking our relative home to die. Ninewells have failed our relative and failed us in the worst way. We experienced terrible communication, untruths and poor care for someone we held dear to our hearts. We have requested a copy of all medical notes and intend on raising several concerns and complaints. No family or patient should endure what we have. I worry for the patients without advocates. What of their health and well-being? Basic human rights? We aim to make the disgraces we experienced public and refuse to accept poor practise under the banner of ‘It’s Covid, times are hard.’

author: bambitommy
title: Social prescribing helps me cope and help others
body:
I am a tenant of SYHA, I have a house. I have lived in Cantley for about 16 years. Our house in Hyde Park was pulled down and we moved. We were a family of 4 now I am on my own. When my husband was terminally ill five year ago I had a lot of help from St Ledgers' Homes under their terminal health care arrangements, they did a number of adaptations around the house including the bathroom. This helped me to care for him as I nursed him at home in the last few months of his life.  
My GP recommended me for Social Prescribing and through this contact I became a Social Prescribing volunteer myself. I now go out with a Social Prescribing coordinator to visit potential clients referred by GPs. If the person wants to take part I visit them on a regular basis. On average I make three separate visits a week each of about an hour. Not only is the person who wants the service getting a benefit I am too because it helps me cope with my own loneliness and the continuing bereavement.  
I have enjoyed the training courses including one on helping people in bereavements and another on working with partially sighted clients. I had a career in a caring professional and love to be able to continue to meet with people.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: Patsy Finnegan
title: Appointment for a blood test
body: The nurse was excellent, very caring and understanding

author: Duncanjb13
title: Exceptional care
body: I’ve put my back out and I’m miserable, the pain is so intense I can’t stop myself from crying sometimes. All the nurses are great but I was told they were really sorry but I couldn't have anymore painkillers. Two nurses Rose and Anne went out of their way to call a Dr and get me stronger painkillers Tramadol, Pregabalin and something else and when I took them it was the first relief I’ve had that actually worked and made me comfortable. I’m so grateful to them because everybody else was just saying I can’t have anymore but Anne and Rose recognised I needed something much stronger. Thank you so much. I see the staff are run off their feet and exhausted but nothing was too much for them and they are a credit to the NHS. A HUGE THANK YOU.

author: jp2020
title: Urgent treatment centre
body:
Attended with headache, racing heart and other symptoms, received ecg and waited for doctor.  
Doctor came, told me all about my anxiety and that it was just my anxiety causing it. Following day I attended again after being told by 111 to attend for a repeat ecg. Doctor seen was completely different, he insisted I needed to be seen at Boston accident and emergency and he would call an ambulance.  
I returned home and attended myself. Received all necessary tests and was returned to care of GP. All in all was not over-impressed with the level of care provided by the first doctor at urgent care.

readBy.name: Lincolnshire Community Health Services NHS Trust

author: jp2020
title: Very uninformative
body: Attended medical practice to speak to reception as advised to see GP regarding on going symptoms. The staff at reception were very uninformative, went to back room spoke to the duty doctor in room full of staff with regards to my problem, came back and they asked where the letter was. I explained there was no letter as they had no printing facilities due to server down, and they asked why it hadn't been hand written. I said just to leave it and asked what I do about booking an appointment, was told in a rude manner that appointments are on the day for the day, ring back Monday at 8am and I might get one. What a complete joke.

author: Ajprfc
title: Procedure to my ear
body:
Outpatients appointment at F.V.R.H.  
Excellent covid precautions in place from entering hospital to and including day surgery.  
Procedure explained in detail and fully understood, all went very well and my questions were all answered by Kirsty and Aileen.  
I was well looked after at all times, many thanks to both ladies Kirsty and Aileen

author: SRH-H
title: Ectopic pregnancy surgery
body:
I had a second ectopic pregnancy in 3 months and felt shocked alone, with my husband not being allowed in the ward.  
I went for an assessment but the pain intensified greatly and I had to be admitted and operated on that night.  
Wendy, who cared for me on Branston ward, was a guiding light. She could sense my despair and fear and stayed with me as much as possible. It was like having my mum there! I am so thankful for her, and the care of other staff members on Branston who treated me with empathy and respect. They gave their time to listen when I needed to offload emotionally.

author: AGC chatterbox
title: Excellent service received by all staff
body: Admitted as emergency to AU2 and transferred to ward 54.   Whilst in hospital I was in theatre for 6 hours and spent 2 days in  HDU before being transferred back to ward 54 where I remained for a week.   After being discharged I had to attend radiology department a week later and then seen by Urology.   I have nothing. but praise for every member of staff who has been involved in my care.   I was treated with respect by all nurses Consultants Radiologists and Urology department.   My whole stay at VHK was made easier by the kindness of all staff involved.

author: sharonc110
title: My recent time as inpatient
body: This has been my fifth stay in ward 207 in Aberdeen royal infirmary.   I have had a very complex problem which has not been easily resolved. During each stay I have been overwhelmed with the professionalism of the staff and the care given, especially in these current unprecedented times. I was shown dignity, love and support which made a very difficult time for me bearable. At every stage of my care everything was explained, tests organised in a timely manor and great communication. Words cannot express my appreciation to all of those involved in my care.

readBy.name: Office of Stewart Stevenson, MSP for Banffshire and Buchan Coast

author: Mclean60
title: End of Life care
body:
Father had a stroke and was taken to our local hospital by ambulance. Hospital is Borders General Hospital, Scottish Borders.  
Ambulance staff were professional and reassuring.  
Father finished in Stroke Unit/Palliative Care ward and all staff were amazing, so caring and reassuring

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland
St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: warmfq65
title: Pharmacy staff
body: I was waiting to collect a prescription from Boots pharmacy. The receptionist was abrupt, rude and loudly announced my medical problems. I waited for over 35 minutes and when I asked about the time I was given an equally rude response. I was upset nearly to the point of tears about theway I was spoken to.

author: Lms078
title: Minor Operation
body: I had a minor operation carried out today at Forth Valley by Lisa and David and everything went well. Although the car park was busy I found a car parking space, entry to the hospital was monitored which was good as it ensured everyone used sanitiser and also had masks on.   I went to the Day surgery ward and sat in a sectioned off seating area.   David came and took me through to the room where the procedure was to be done and introduced me to Lisa.   Both Lisa and David chatted before, through and after the procedure which made me forget about what was happening. I felt very comfortable with Covid restrictions being followed. Thanks to both of them.

author: monocerosmt79
title: Lack of Support, Follow Up or Care.
body:
My child has been under the care (in the loosest sense of the word) of Paediatrics at Crosshouse since birth and Rainbow House for the past three years.  
I have almost no complaints about the paediatric department at Crosshouse with one exception - the paediatric continence team. We met with them ONCE about two or three years ago and they have failed to follow up or contact us since despite many requests from a consultant, health visitor and GP to do so. As it currently stands my child who is almost 6 years remains unsupported and we have no resources or support with her incontinence and constipation issues. This is the same child who is similarly unsupported by Rainbow House.  
We have gone round in circles since she was referred with no real plan or view for diagnosis. There has been NO contact nor input from the doctor or their team in 12 months and I’m sorry to say that I now have little to no confidence in those who are meant to be supporting a child who very clearly needs some sort of support which she is unable to access due to the reluctance of those caring for her to commit to a diagnosis. 6 years old with a speech delay, incontinence and a hearing issue that is struggling her way through p1 when she can actually attend never mind when they can’t and she has NO support other than from myself, my partner and my mother.  
We’re at a stage now where we are having to purchase incontinence products because nobody will provide a diagnosis of anything which we have been told is required to access prescription incontinence pants for her as children’s products no longer fit nor are appropriate. The lack of input and support is affecting her all round as it is all of us as we can only do so much!!

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Taurus91
title: Birth Experience - 5th time around
body:
At the end of January I gave birth to my 5th baby.  
I wanted to write to you, to make you aware of how wonderful the experience was during my labour with your midwife Lauren.  
Giving birth four times before, I new what to expect and a clear plan in mind for pain relief, delayed cord clamping ect  
Lauren talked through each part with myself an my fiancé as we where preparing for everything to begin.  
I want to thank her, She gave me two of the best gifts I could have ever asked for—my daughter, and a positive birthing experience.  
She made me feel comfortable 100% of the time.  
She respected the way I wanted to give birth. Listened to me—really listened.  
They're was no pressure for me to do anything, they're was no continually questioning me how I was feeling. She let me tell her when I was ready to push (which seemed early, but was the case)  
I think what's most important to me, thinking back on my birth stories, is that Lauren was with me throughout the whole process of labour and delivery. Not here and there, not just the end when I needed to push—the whole time.  
I hope you pass on our gratefulness.  
I would also like to mention to Rebekah in Triage, Rebekah had been my midwife 3 pregnancies ago before been moved to triage. Anytime I visited triage or phone an got her she was always very helpful and so friendly.  
She always put my mind at ease, an listened. Im internally grateful to her for been there for me on that day when I got to triage with pain and just a sense something was not right, she was fabulous at keeping me calm , following all her producers & although nothing was majorly coming up on the monitor, she believed me and remembered this situation from my previous pregnancy.  
She accompanied me up to the ward to get settled, a felt frightened but she reassured me..  
An for that I'm so grateful

author: Hapax
title: Major heart operation
body:
My operation was conducted in the Royal Infirmary Edinburgh, but pre- and post-care was in the Borders General Hospital. Of the 37 days I was in hospital more than 30 were in the BGH. I returned a month later to the BGH for another 5 days.  
Every aspect of care was outstanding, but I must single out the nurses: nothing was too much trouble; it was as though we were members of the same family. Every day was a series of laughs. Another aspect that deserves special mention is the food: nutritious, generous, tasty, like Granny makes it.  
I can find nothing to criticise.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: waggw69
title: treatment for bile duct cancer
body:
Hi, i recently had clearance from my 10th annual scan and i have since been fully discharged. I would like to give my best wishes and thanks to all at Derby Royal and Queens Med Nottingham for their wonderful treatment during my illness and aftercare. Its a bit more than just treatment isn't it! at times of despair the compassion and positive attitude shown by all staff involved at both hospitals gives you hope to fight this disease, and proves that a positive attitude can be a massive help.  
I am forever in your debt, once again many thanks

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Derby and Burton NHS Foundation Trust

author: couragent78
title: Bowel surgery giving me my life back
body: I had a stoma formed in 2019 due to a perforated bowel I was originally told a reversal wouldn’t be possible due to radiation damage I then suffered a prolapse which affected the quality of my life badly I got a second opinion from dr Michelle who done a successful reversal giving me back my life I can’t thank this lady enough, she done operation within 2 days of seeing me no messing about, a truly wonderful skilled professional.

author: Mr RJ
title: Multiple tests
body: Admitted at the beginning of February for tests. All staff were first rate, offering a caring, professional service. I was very impressed. Thank you all.

readBy.name: Surrey and Sussex Healthcare NHS Trust

author: CSDoddsSB
title: My Dads care
body:
My Dad (90 y/o) was taken by ambulance into our local Borders hospital on 28th December with a suspected stroke. (Borders General Hospital, Melrose, Scotland)  
From the medics in ambulance to his palliative care he could not have received better care and attention.  
In Stroke Unit/Palliative ward the nursing staff were so attentive and, as we were unable to visit him, they took our calls and passed on messages to Dad. All this was done in a gracious way.  
When Dad was in his last few days he was in a side room and we were able to visit anytime. Nothing was too much bother and Covid-19 rules were strictly adhered to.  
The palliative team were outstanding and, though they were short staffed and working long hours, their care and gentleness was such a comfort to us all x

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: May37
title: My dads care
body:
My dad was unfortunately end of life in Ward 18. The care and support that dad received was absolutely amazing. We were given the opportunity to be with dad 24/7 and the staff also looked after and supported us too for nearly two weeks. Under such challenging times too!  
Every single staff member we were involved with regardless of their role showed us nothing but compassion. I honestly can’t rate this ward or their staff highly enough.

author: JackC63
title: 1st COVID vaccination
body: A very smooth system all the staff were friendly and always at hand to help.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: suncc66
title: Breast screening
body:
I attended the mobile breast screening unit on the 4th of February at Earlston health centre in the Borders. The staff were welcoming and friendly. This was my first time and they explained everything well and treated me with respect.  
Thank you - you are doing a great job

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: redpq77
title: Amazing Support through a tough time losing a baby
body:
My wife and I went through IVF in November 2020, we had amazing news that she was pregnant and had our 8 week scan booked in for New Years Eve. Heartbreakingly, there was no heartbeat on the scan so we had lost the baby.  
The first round of medical management on New Year’s Eve didn’t work, likely due to the high level of hormones from the IVF treatment, so the process of bringing on a miscarriage was drawn out 5 weeks into early Feb 2021.  
The nurses and doctors in Lincoln Branston ward and Hemswell clinic were absolutely brilliant, despite the emotional and physical pain we were both in, they did everything they could to comfort us and make sure the horrible process of miscarriage was dealt with sensitively. They all took time to talk to us and listen to us and how we were feeling throughout the day in hospital.  
Thank you to everyone on Branston ward and Hemswell ward, you made an antagonising situation more bearable and helped us get through it.

author: Alfaromeo
title: In excellent hands
body: Went in on the 3rd Feb 2020 to have the procedure carried out on my prostate using the new cutting edge technology off Green light laser prostatectomy. From arriving until it was time to leave, every one   of the staff were excellent and very reassuring. I was going in thinking I was going to have a general aesthetic but the anaesthetist explained to me about a spinal anaesthetic, have to admit I was a little bit apprehensive about it. Turned out it was no problem whatsoever. Just took a bit of time to get the feeling back in my lower part of my body. As I say, I was well looked after with no complaints whatsoever. P. S. the trainees were very good as well, if they are to be our nurses in the future then we will be in excellent hands.

author: Jenna6121
title: Thankful for the care & delivery of our daughter
body:
I cannot thank the Midwives and Midwife Assistants at Ayrshire Maternity unit enough. They were truly wonderful and lovely and helped us so much during the birth of our daughter on 26th January.  
Christine was our midwife on the nightshift and she was outstanding, so friendly and caring. We are also so grateful to Lisa the midwife who delivered our baby and was so kind and sympathetic.  
Also a big thank you to MW Susanne, MWA Allison and all the Medical team who were lovely.  
Thank you for your care and for delivering our daughter. Such a good experience and brilliant care during a time that can be very scary and nerve wracking.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Wawa
title: They all need medals
body:
So my doctor sent me to hospital , once I arrived at the a and e department I gave my letter , the staff got me to a chair as I was in a lot of pain , I was in the wrong area so a member of staff came and got me , I was crying at this point and they got me straight in to talk to someone who , soon got me booked in and through into a room for me to lay down !!  
In a and e , the staff were very friendly and couldn’t do anymore for me, checked me regular and asked how pain level was and was there to talk and listen when I needed to say how I felt ! In a lot of pain they got tests done quickly and efficiently and they got me on the gynae ward for further tests !  
Once on the ward the staff there were amazing !! Nothing was too much trouble ( they actually told me off for not pressing the buzzer , when I was in pain cos I didn’t want to be a hindrance ) they made time to comfort me and were very professional at the same time , although we going through a pandemic , the staff on ward 1B at pilgrim hospital made me feel I was with friends , they sat with me for 15-20 min which was like having family or friends visit . They diverted my attention when having mental health issues at 5:30 in the morning , they all deserve medals !! I cannot praise them enough !!  
Thank you , this made my hospital experience a little more bearable , I highly recommended anyone needing to be in the care of pilgrim hospital

author: OJED
title: Covid 19 vaccination
body: Arrived at clinic, Lakeside Centre Craigavon, entered queue for vaccination. Smooth transition through registration to the nurse. Nurse was great, good conversation and would make anyone feel relaxed about the process. Received vaccine and waited 15 minutes.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: willy wonka
title: Excellent
body: just been to Craigavon in N. I. to be vaccinated. EXCELLENT  system in operation. Nurses and volunteers doing a fantastic job thank you.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Kamo
title: Great care
body: I've been very well looked after the in all aspects in my weeks stay in the Medical 2 and MAU wards in Causeway Hospital, from domestic staff in cleaning my room with a chat and a smile, catering staff providing great food and many cups of tea, nursing staff are all friendly and very helpful nothing is a problem to them even with all the patients under their care, all Doctors F1 to consultant's have been very attentive to my symptoms and have been quick to react in ordering tests to find out what was happening.

readBy.name: Northern Health and Social Care Trust

author: ChasBabe
title: Couldn't have been better
body: Couldn’t have been a better experience. Staff were very professional but also so nice to everyone that I came in contact with whilst I was there. The injection itself was really painless, just a hardly imperceptible prick. Would certainly recommend the Ulster hospital to anyone booking a jab. My utmost heartfelt thanks to all the staff.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Brassy
title: Covid vaccine
body: Received my 1st covid vaccine today at Craigavon site. So well organised. Thanks to all the staff and volunteers. In and out in 15 minutes. Fantastic service.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Roycekofi
title: Covid-19 vaccine
body: Went to south lakes leisure centre for my vaccination this morning. I found the whole setup to be very satisfactory. All the staff were more than helpful and the nurse who gave me my jab was most informative about the vaccination. In all I found the whole journey from arrival to leaving totally stress free well done southern trust

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: caelumgn46
title: Telephone medicine review/ check-up
body:
I was transferred from Stonebridge to NeSS and had a scheduled review today. I have had something similar in the past and understand the necessity for the lack of F2F. The appointment today, however, was truly noteworthy. Mr Singh was absolutely exceptional! He was professional and thorough but also compassionate. He was holistic (an approach I very much appreciate) but also specific. As the 'exam' progressed, I felt able to be more personal than I normally would (especially on a phone call). Far, far more than what I would expect from a 'routine' prescription check, by the end the call was personal, encouraging, and positive, if not inspiring.  
It took me 3 decades to learn that I need help managing mental health issues. Since then I have been extremely appreciative of MH professionals: I want and am trying to 'get better' and I really want to thank everyone who helps with that. Even just after today's phone call, I feel that talking with Mr. Singh has already helped considerably.  
I can honestly say the discussion we had today was a very positive human interaction -- which are rare for me in these days.

author: dunblane
title: small head operation
body: Thanks to David and Lisa at Forth Valley Hospital  for putting me at my ease before and during my operation.   Both were what I would expect from my health service, Polite informative and totally professional.

author: Grahamf
title: Radiotherapy Treatment, Western General Hospital
body:
I wish to thank the team who operate LA1 for their care and attention.  
I underwent a series of radiotherapy treatments for prostate cancer commencing in early January and completing in February.  
On arrival on the first day I was met by one of the team. She greeted me with professionalism and kindness. The Team made me feel very comfortable throughout the period of treatments. Any question was answered in full and to satisfaction.  
Please pass on my appreciation to the initial team member and the whole team.  
The radiotherapy department of The Western General Hospital deserves great praise.

author: guidefx98
title: Smooth process
body: Smooth process. Everything explained clearly. Everyone more than helpful. Willing to assist with any questions

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: velafx74
title: Colonoscopy yesterday
body: Staff were wonderful and I would like to say a huge thank you to Anna Louise and Bobby and especially to Dr Sengupta, Julie, and Carol. I was so well cared for and continually checked and reassured that I was ok during the procedure. Massive thank you to everyone. Also a huge thank you to Mr Yalamarthi and his team.

author: Manxshearwater
title: My brother's cancer care.
body: Hugh had terminal brain tumor, diagnosed in 2017. The care he received from the Royal Victoria Hospital Belfast, The Cancer Center@ Belfast City Hospital and the South Eastern Trust home care was exceptional throughout. Words cannot convey our gratitude for the professional and compassionate service of everyone... from medical, nursing. admin and ancillary staff. Truly awesome. We were so fortunate to be allowed to be with him in his final days in January in the cancer center. In this pandemic  so many people have been denied that. Have been humbled by the true dedication and kindness. These are the real hero's to whom we owe so much. We in turn must ensure our government looks after them now and in the future. We cannot fail them.

readBy.name: Belfast Health and Social Care Trust
South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: humanitiesge83
title: My daughter had a reaction from her 4-1 booster
body: My daughter had a severe reaction from her booster. I spoke to my own GP who prescribed me an antibiotic to treat it... from the minute I got it the injection sight kept flaring up. : I spoke to NHS 24 who were really helpful and then my own GP again... I felt there was no interest there on my concerns all based on covid and not wanting   seeing patients ... I was advised to go to hospital... I went to Wishaw general where I was triaged straight away with my daughter and then waited in the a& e area to be seen by a doctor... time passed and it thought wise to send me to ward 19 to be seen by a doctor... I was seen by a 5th year medical student, Then a doctor and then a consaultant before we were relised to go home... everyone who treated us from the nurses to the doctors were amazing! I felt like I was listened to and not made to feel stupid for having a worries during this pandemic. I completely appreciate we are in hard times but I wouldn’t have visited the hospital unless I needed to.. thank you so much to the staff who treated my daughter. She felt so comfortable and I was given solid advice. You are all doing an amazing job x

readBy.name: North Lanarkshire Health & Social Care Partnership

author: Talula
title: My sons injury
body: We arrived at the children’s a and e in the evening my son had an injury and it needed to be xrayed my son has special needs and was extremely anxious and worried, we was seen so fast within 30 minutes we had been triaged and xrayed. My son kept saying how nice everybody was ( this is extremely rare for him to comment on this) the staff offered him a drink checked on his well-being whilst waiting had a little joke with him to keep him at ease. With everything going on in this pandemic all the a and e staff in the children’s department I cannot fault they are a huge credit to darenth valley: )

author: plutozw94
title: Just a wee scratch
body: I was approached by a lovely nurse Danielle at South Lake Leisure Centre who explained everything to me asking me the relevant questions. I had received my vaccine and didnt realise I had it done she said just a wee scratch and thats all it was. I cant praise her enough for her the professional way all was carried out. Thank you Danielle

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cheetahej69
title: Anxiety and panic attacks
body: I was suffering increased stress and anxiety at home and at work which eventually led to severe panic attacks, irritability and low mood. I called Thurrock inclusion and had the help of Leanne, who through weekly phone calls made me understand how to change my mindset as well as give practical tips tohelp me deal with my anxiety and panic.

author: grandad dave
title: Colonoscopy
body:
Superb throughout my time in the Endoscopy Department. Obviously I wasn't particularly looking forward to the Colonoscopy Procedure but relieved to find out I was clear of anything suspicious.  
Suffice to say every single member of staff were brilliant regarding my care and Colonoscopy Procedure by my friendly Endoscopist? Maybe needs to work on his Sean Connery impersonations😀😀  
Having said all that I hope I'm not back anytime soon for more plumbing work.  
Lastly I opted for NO Sedation and apart from some cramps during the procedure it was a breeze.. Personally I would recommend No Sedation but obviously this is the patients choice.  
After about 30 minutes in the recovery ward with a Cup of Coffee provided I was dressed and on my way home.  
Thanks to all at PRI Endoscopy Suite😉

author: errandkw35
title: Colonoscopy
body:
I had this procedure at PRI last week at 16.15.  
I should like to thank Maureen for her great care ,dedication and humour  
The procedures was carried out magnificently and so very gently that it was finished before I realised it was over.  
A special thank you also to Steph and the other nurse in the room ( sorry did not get name )  
Also a special thank you to the nurse who welcomed me into the department and the nurse too in the Recovery room ( again sorry for not remembering your names )  
I am so grateful and honoured that people like these work for NHS  
Thank you  
PS I noticed on the day 59 patients failed to turn up in January for appointments  
These people ought to be severely fined particularly during this pandemic !

author: corvusqm54
title: Excellent and reassuring visit
body:
Had small procedures .felt really safe staff were really great. Always nervous about hospital but were excellent and reassuring .  
So thank you to da and Aileen

author: N Levett
title: My Grandmother care.
body:
On Thursday this week my Grandmother, Isobella, was admitted to Forth Valley Royal hospital, due to contracting covid. Sadly she lost her very hard fought battle with it.  
Her care throughput was exemplary. From her admission in AAU to the care she recieved from the staff in A32.  
All the staff were absolutely brilliant and credit to fvrh. Showing compassion and care to my gran at all times.  
I would like to pay particular praise to nurse Lindsey (sorry if spelling is wrong) in A32. Throughout she was compassionate and professional, offering me and my gran support, emotional and physical, throughout my grans final hours to an exceptionally high standard.  
She worked with me at this point to ensure that at the end my gran, could pass with some peace and dignity. This effort and care from her will stay with me forever and went far and beyond. I hope she knows how special to my family she was in them two nights.  
She said to me how well I seemed to handle what at times was a very distressing time for my gran and very hard to watch. She doesn't know this calm reaction was partly due to how caring she was. It took a few hours after my grans passing for the grief to set in. But this grief was eased due to the care she received by Lindsay and all in A32.  
Thanks to all the staff at fvrh.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: reticulumkt43
title: Colonoscopy
body:
I had to go for a colonoscopy at Queen Margaret Hospital in Dunfermline this morning after I had a positive result from my Bowel Test. , even though I’d had no symptoms whatsoever.  
The pre- procedure care a few days beforehand, talking me through what would happen was first class. I had to have a COVID test as well and self isolate beforehand, not difficult as the weather was abysmal. This morning on arrival at the hospital at 8. 15am, I was seen quickly, met the endoscopist, Mr Amin who is lovely, and before I knew it the procedure was going ahead. I’ve never had an endoscopy before but know a few who have.  
The nurses, Lesley and Yvonne were amazing, so kind and considerate as was Mr Amin. It was all over in 1/2 hour! . Apart from a bit of discomfort going round the ‘corners’ it was ok and I only needed a couple of breaths of Entinox, and no need for sedation fortunately. The aftercare was great, I felt very safe and cared for the whole time I was there and even better there is nothing untoward, just one of those things, but better to be safe than sorry.  
I’ve done bowel tests since I was 50 and this was the first positive one. A colonoscopy is not something you’d want to do every day but having it done at that early stage usually means if there is anything untoward it can be dealt with quickly, It gave me great peace of mind. Remember always do your bowel test! ! The tea and toast after was very welcome!

author: Covid Vaccination
title: I can't praise everyone highly enough
body: After receiving a very quick appointment on line I attended the Ulster Hospital on Saturday Jan 30th for my vaccine. Right from the sign posting, parking attendants, security at the door, volunteer greeter, admin staff and finally to the nursing staff, I can't praise everyone highly enough for how pleasant they were and how well organised the experience was. Well done and thank you.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Janet e
title: Excellent service
body: Just had my first vaccination this am, excellent  service  and all staff polite  and helpful. Keep up the good work

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust
South Ayrshire Health and Social Care Partnership

author: Greig 82
title: I was admitted with acute heart failure
body:
Terrible, but was treated with the most professional people I have ever had the pleasure of meeting. Nothing was to much trouble and they all had time to have just a few words of encouragement, this ranged from the housekeeping staff to the Consultants, and as for the nursing staff well I cannot praise them enough.  
How they all manage to keep as happy when with patients is beyond me.  
I really did not like being in hospital but to be cared for by such a devoted staff really improved my stay no end.  
I cannot thank you all enough

author: Bilser
title: The whole exercise was very professional
body:
Our 65 to 69 category vaccinations were received today at South Lakes Leisure Centre, Craigavon.
From start to finish it was around 30 minutes and the whole exercise was very professional, well organised, friendly and felt totally safe.
We look forward to our second jab in April and in the meantime we intend to continue following the guidelines as if we haven’t yet been vaccinated.
Hopefully the younger population can receive their jabs sooner than expected.
Overall, we are hugely impressed with the efficiency of the roll out.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: snowbengal
title: Had no worries
body:
MY visit today was good. Staff were really nice and helpful..Talked me through everything that was happening. Made me at ease. Had no worries , I was very relaxed.  
[Happy with 'Staff skills']

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: caringjm73
title: A brilliant team
body: I attended A& E the other evening following a fall. Have to say I cannot praise the staff enough. I was seen promptly, staff were very polite, all in all brilliant team 👏

readBy.name: The Dudley Group NHS Foundation Trust

author: kevinams870
title: Healthcare at home and home care services
body: The best way to recover faster from an ailment is by spending quality time with your loved ones, and that’s why getting the required healthcare at home is crucial. This struck me when my sister was bedridden for a brief period and had to be admitted to the hospital. She never wanted that, instead wanted to get home as soon as possible. Someone had to stay back home to take care of her, so we started looking for options. A friend’s friend had recommended Abicare to us at that time. I quickly checked it out and got in touch with them. They heard us out patiently and explained the home care services they provide. We were looking for someone who could be with her 24/7 and on hearing that Abicare provided live-in care, we were more than happy. The carer assigned to my sister was very sweet and caring. She ensured my sister’s meals and medications were provided on time. She would try and include my sister in activities to keep her entertained at all times. We couldn’t have asked for someone better.

author: Stephw2001
title: Excellent person centred care
body: Over the last couple of months my elderly mother has required medication review/changes to control her blood pressure. To minimise unnecessary visits to the GP under the current circumstances we have been communicating with her GP Dr Alexander at Bourtreehill Medical Practice by email and occasionally by telephone. We have had swift responses when contacting the surgery and excellent communication between the surgery and Care Pharmacy, Springside resulting in mums care being safely and effectively managed without the risk involved by visiting the GP in person. I wanted to thank both Dr Alexander, surgery staff and staff at Care Pharmacy for providing excellent person centred care during these extremely difficult times.

author: snowday
title: Waiting times
body:
I feel awful. How on earth has the wait time jumped another 14months for just a first appointment that's nearly 4years my soul is absolute destroyed. I do not believe covid is an acceptable excuses at all as I know full well people have had more than 6 appointments in this time also the waiting time had already increased due to covid.  
I was told that first appointments are happening but I find this hard to believe looking at the figures. How many first appointments have actually happened since 2018 I believe very few but I know you won't actually answer. I'll be lucky if I am seen before I turn 40 the effect on my mental health is immense due this excruciating wait. How can you treat people like this. I know this will just get some generic comment from someone in management saying they are sorry and they are doing all they can but they aren't clearly. what we want is some actually answers and some care.

readBy.name: Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)

author: elreevio231
title: Unacceptable
body: Not sure what the other surgerys are like but my experience from wessex road has gone down hill severely since being taken over by Shore medical ...45 mins and still no answer this has happened on numerous occasions (understand about covid but 12 months in! ! ), prescriptions being sent to the wrong pharmacy (20 miles away) not being able to get my diabetic medications on time (sometimes have to go without of even borrow from friends! ! ! ) Think the staff deserve a holiday and shore medical should get more people in to help them its clear they need more staff.

author: Froshaug
title: Lack of joined up services after CRPS diagnosis
body:
Lack of joined up services for my daughter after CRPS diagnosis  
Firstly, I'd like to say that I appreciate what a trying time it is for everyone who works within the NHS. Although it's possibly the worst time to need medical attention, everyone we've seen or talked to so far has treated us with great care and attention, and we really appreciate everything that's been done for us so far.  
My nine year old daughter was sent to A&E at Sandwell Hospital just before Christmas with extreme pain in her left leg which came on overnight. After a week or so in and out of hospital she was given a diagnosis of Complex Regional Pain Syndrome and discharged, with care to be taken up by a consultant neurologist at Birmingham Children's Hospital.  
CRPS is a complex condition requiring a range of care to work towards recovery, but we seem to have slipped into a gap between the initial care at Sandwell and Birmingham Children's Hospital taking up our daughter's case. In the meantime, we feel like we've been abandoned to deal with things ourselves, using what little good quality information we've been able to find online. She's had one physio appointment since she left hospital, and one counselling session which we organised ourselves. We had to organise our own wheelchair and my wife's currently going round in circles trying to organise an OT, having been directed towards a service who told her that they wouldn't deal with someone with CRPS because 'we only deal with neurological conditions' (Which CRPS is).  
The consultant at BCH wanted her to have nerve conduction studies done before her appointment, and we were told an appointment would come through soon. We'd heard nothing by the second week of January so decided to chase up and were told, although she was on the system at BCH, no referral had been made for the studies, and the consultant was away for the whole of January. The receptionist said she'd get someone else to look into the referral and get back to us, but no-one did, so we had to chase up, also speaking again to the really helpful paediatrician at Sandwell who initially referred us. Despite weeks of this we've evidently had to wait for the consultant to return for the process to begin, and it’ll be almost a month from diagnosis before the studies are done and obviously even later to see the consultant.  
All the information we've managed to find so far stresses the importance of acting quickly on CRPS, with the time taken to start proper treatment having a major effect on the time it takes to recover. Obviously we're not medically trained, but it's clear that our daughter's visibly regressing. The exercises given to us by the physio are too much for her to tolerate, and we're constantly having to push her to do exercises she finds extremely painful (we tried to ask about the medication she's been given to control the pain, but again were told this would have to wait until the consultants return).  
We keep thinking she might be making slight progress with bending her knee, but if anything that’s plateaued too. She can no longer flex her foot, which she could when she left hospital. She can't wear her tracksuit bottoms or tolerate bathing, both of which she could earlier. It's having a huge effect on her mental health, with ever more frequent panic attacks, and she keeps telling us that she wishes she could die. It feels completely brutal, and without any indication of how we move forward from here, it feels like we've been left to fend for ourselves.

readBy.name: Birmingham Women's and Children's NHS Foundation Trust

author: charaje44
title: steps2change Lincolnshire complaint
body:
I was given a weekly telephone apt after referal from the GP.  
They gave me an over-simplified service which offered nothing more than goal setting over the phone rather than in your journal. They know you're self-aware enough to set your own goals, because you have decided to seek help, this is a very patronising service which did not support me.  
After a 13 week wait for an appointment, I cannot believe how poor this service is. Appointments are only 20 minutes long and they tried to avoid listening to my personal situation as much as possible and instead try to set minute goals for the week (something I've undoubtedly tried in the 3 months waiting for an appointment, let alone before). It is so incredibly difficult opening up to somebody and facing your struggles head on, and when that is met with a deaf ear and a rushed 20 minute appointment trying to pigeon hole you into one of the 2 CBT courses they offer (either setting goals to get you out of the house if you have anxiety or setting small goals to get you doing things you cannot do because of depression) this understandably compounds your belief that nobody wants to or is able to help you. Shocking.  
When I expressed that I was feeling rushed and unheard, I was told "I don't think so". Incredibly unprofessional. Furthermore, the therapist spending a large proportion of the 20 minute appointment talking about themselves. The therapist was repeatedly 5 minutes late to this already short slot - who on earth is going to understand the complexity and desperation of your situation after three 15 minute phone calls (especially when they talk about themselves more than listening to you). The scores that you have to fill in each week to assess your current state were checked at the very end of the appointment when there is no time remaining to discuss your thoughts or feelings.  
I politely raised all of my concerns with the therapist who gave me a lot of attitude and was extremely defensive and asked me "what would you like us to do?". I am shocked, I was just looking for some help.  
This service was far far too simplified to offer actual mental health support for me as person who has been suffering for more than 2 weeks. Which is everyone trying to access the service, given that the wait time is at least 12 weeks.

author: Harry1
title: Asthma follow up
body: I was to have a follow up telephone appointment with respiratory nurse on 7/1/21 however this didn’t happen even though nurse called to confirm I was sent a letter with appointment date 3/2/21 and was told to ignore this as they had brought my appointment forward, when I didn’t receive a phone call I contacted appointment s and was told there has been a mixup and that I would be called on the 3/2/21 again this never happened and I called appointments again and was go talk number to call however this seems to out of service

author: muzza138
title: 12 hours - no doctor, no information
body:
12 hours - no doctor, no information regarding test result or diagnosis  
I waited for 12 hours after attending A& E with heart pain, breathing difficulties and headaches. Was triaged quickly in A& E having arrived at 9. 30am - had numerous tests  
I was then sent onto IAC unit at 3pm. Waited until 8pm before asking what was happening, was told the doctor would be round imminently. I waited until 9. 00pm and asked again - one of the nurses seated at the nurses station asked why I hadn't; t asked what was happening before, which of course I had. Another nurse intervened and said that I had been waiting since 3pm and not received any information at all no had I been seen by a doctor. Both nurses agreed this was not usual not was it acceptable.  
I informed them that my husband was en route back to the hospital to take me home, having already waited for 7 hours outside. The trip is a 40 minute drive each way. at 9. 35pm, still no doctor and no information - I discharged myself.

author: Dragongirl4
title: Maternity care
body:
My pregnancy was with the community midwife team and Wishaw hospital and never again. I honestly wanted another baby and this feeling has been taken from me, I haven't been listened to, ignored, and not offered help in anyway for my mental health. Triage was just as bad, was left in worse condition than when I went in bleeding etc.  
Family members are livid at the treatment received, mental health more so, as it's at all time high with covid and lockdown and to be ignored at all is dangerous in my opinion let alone being pregnant too.Worst maternity treatment I have ever had in my life honestly have no idea the harm caused to my family, my kids, my unborn baby and my mum etc due to their attitude towards it all.

readBy.name: South Lanarkshire Health and Social Care Forum

author: hekaxs97
title: Getting a diagnosis for my dad
body: Dad became unwell in March with suspected covid. Out of all of us who fell ill I said at the time he got off the lightest however I don't think he did. Over the past year I've seen my very active dad who is in his late 70's and could walk 10 miles easily, go from this to being stooped, losing weight, being sick and having shakes in his hands. It took a few trips to the doctors (having to be covid negative first) and my brothers intervention to get a referral to a neurologist. However I know this is a pandemic we are in but how long does it take to be referred bearing in mind we are constantly told the NHS is still open for business? It's awful to see him go down hill so quickly when I know there is medication to improve his quality of life.

readBy.name: Office of Colin Smyth, MSP for South Scotland

author: Bhaijaan
title: Wasting bed space
body: I was discharged by the emergency team but the diabetic team took a whole day to come and just prepare the discharge letters. If the government has so much money to waste on waiting patients, they should stop moaning about the NHS budget. It would surely be cheaper to hire more staff and diabetic specialists rather than wasting bed space for a whole day.

author: Lesley A
title: Lack of general care due to covid
body:
I have been back in Scotland for over a year, and 10 months in North Lanarkshire.  
I have Rheumatoid Arthritis, Ehlers Danlos Syndrome, severe hearing loss, very painful tendinitis and problems with a sublaxing shoulder which causes pain and numbness. I also suffer from Depression, and as a result of the pain I am always in, and the fact that I have not been given my usual anti-depressant medication, it has just got worse.  
I can't walk properly due to excessive pain in my achilles and feet, and that has now caused problems with my knees, which already have osteoarthritis and my hip which was under control, but has now relapsed.  
I have not been able to sleep through the night for months. I always wake up several times a night in pain and have to use ice spray and take more pain medication in order to go back to sleep.  
On arriving here in North Lanarkshire I was on several treatment plans and all of these problems were being managed well, but none of these have continued due to covid, as well as not being able to get a Psychiatrist/Psychologist/Orthopaedic surgeon/Audiologist/Physiotherapy/acupuncture/pain therapy/ appointment. My conditions call for ongoing management and therefore the 10+ years of previous treatment that I have had has been wasted, as I am back to square one.  
I have only had one GP appointment, which was last week, where the Dr suggested more pain medication and put me on a list for xrays, which may take a while. My GP prescribed Pregabalin, which I am reluctant to take, as I have been on it previously and the side effects were very bad. I have carpal tunnel in both wrists which I was told to get my own splints for as the NHS could not supply these at the moment. I asked if they could assist me with my other health issues as I had not managed to see a GP in 10months, but they said that he could only deal with the shoulder/carpal tunnel problem. The GP is not taking appointments and all of the referrals that have supposedly been done have come to nothing.  
Basically, the only Dr that I have seen in the last year has been the Rheumatologist, who decided not to put me back on the Abatacept Infusion which I have been on for 8 yrs, but said that they are not sure if this will cause long term damage or not, and the referrals to Maxillo-facial (my jaw clicks out of joint, is painful and makes an awful noise when eating), Foot and ankle (Achilles tendonitis & unstability), and ortho (hip & neck pain/instability), I have heard nothing from anyone.  
The GP apparently referred me to the Audiologist last year (I am more than 50% deaf with one hearing aid that works), I have not heard a thing. When I call to ask for batteries, which I incidentally did receive early last year, I am now told I can't have as I have no card from the Audiologist, which I am still waiting to see.  
I was referred to an alternate treatment clinic while still living in Glasgow last Feb, so that I could have acupuncture and physio, which I never actually got to. But apparently they can't offer me that in North Larnarkshire, which makes no sense to me at all.  
I also need to see a gynecological urologist, as I have a severely prolapsed bladder (which has had several surgeries), which I mentioned to my GP, but he said that he could not deal with that at the moment. So have not even been referred.  
In short, I have had basically no help at all for a year and everyone is blaming it on covid. I am 100% aware of how dangerous covid is and have been shielding as was recommended by my GP, but the severe ongoing pain is making my depression worse and with not being supplied with my Bupropion, and with only one hearing aid working and not getting battery supplies my life is getting more difficult by the day.  
If I need to move homes in order to be in an area where I will be offered some sort of care, then I will do so. But I need help in identifying which area would be best.  
My biggest worry is that I will end up being disabled due to having no care and management. Which ultimately would cost a lot more as I would not be able to continue to work.  
Throwing pain medication at me is not a solution and will only make matters worse as these are addictive.  
I am so disillusioned and disappointed with the lack of interest shown by NHS staff, the red tape which is not allowing me access to hearing aid repairs and supplies, the hours that I have spent on the phone trying to get help, and not even getting through to a person. Where do I turn to now? If there is a Dr anywhere in the UK that specialises in Ehlers Danlos, I would love to know about it, so that I can get the help that I need.

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: Yobnos
title: Same day assessment unit.
body:
I ended up here via my GP on Monday 4th January 2021. The whole of the unit was maxed out. A&E was really busy too. Standing room only and hours to wait.  
Long story short, I had THE best care I could ever have wished for. ALL the staff on that day were run off their feet. They had run out of actual clinical rooms (Covid and building works) and yet every member of staff were thorough, kind, efficient and effective.  
The nurse and female Dr i saw both went out of their way to ensure that I was seen quickly and got the care I needed. Both went above and beyond (would remember names if my memory was jogged).  
ALL of the team, including admin, were kind to everyone around whilst under enormous pressure from Senior Management to see more patients than was actually possible.

author: Welshie59
title: My broken leg
body:
I slipped and broke my tibia and fibula on Oct 1st last year.  
An ambulance was swiftly despatched to help me and the crew were very lovely and professional throughout. They took me straight to fracture clinic so I didn’t have to wait in A and E.  
In fracture clinic everyone was so kind and thoughtful. Similarly in X-ray. Although my leg was painful all handling was done carefully and tactfully with appropriate pain relief. I was seen by the doctor on call, who explained everything and a plaster cast was applied. I was then offered a cup of tea and some biscuits which were so welcome!  
I transferred to the ward and had surgery to insert a very big nail the following day. Again everyone was thoughtful and explained everything. I did feel quite nauseous after the anaesthetic but that passed after a few days.  
Doctors checked on my leg regularly through all this time to make sure my circulation and nerves weren’t compromised.  
I was on the ward for 4 days. With no visitors allowed, I was extremely grateful for the support and chat form the lovely HCAs on the ward who were so kind. Not just to me but in particular to another elderly patient who was confused at times. It was very moving to see how kindly her confusion was managed, by talking to her and keeping her company, and I only wish her family could have seen this. No one could wish for more for their relative.  
4 months on, my leg is well healed. The scars are fading fast and I’m sure will be scarcely visible in a few months. I am back to my normal very active life, for which I will always be eternally grateful.  
I have been lucky and needed very little help from the NHS throughout my life, but when I needed help it was there. I cannot fault any of my care and that despite being ill in a pandemic. Best of all, it’s free!  
We must all cherish this very special service and keep it free for everyone.  
I would like to say a massive thank you to everyone who was involved in my care.

author: Lemon Nelly
title: My Mum
body: My Mum was in AAU and ward A32.     The care and treatment was wonderful, in A32 the nurses showed such care and dignity to Mum and us it touched our hearts.   The Dr was in touch with me and was very good and informative in a sensitive manner

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: jupiterzc96
title: Procedures not followed
body:
According to people I have spoken to and what I have seen on TV:  
- The Dr Cleans arm with antiseptic on cottonwool  
- The Dr put plaster on after vaccine done  
- Sit and wait 15 min in observation room  
None of these happened to me.  
And the second appointment date is left blank.

author: aquilaqk98
title: So thoughtful
body:
Not much experience of needing hospital care until recently but found NHS absolutely fantastic.  
1) I had a colonoscopy in November - the pandemic was ongoing so the preparation nurse phoned me re details - explained all - had to go for bloods to South Tyrone after Covid test (negative) in Craigavon Hospital. All went like clockwork. The S.Tyrone nurse even did my hypothyroidism blood test to save me going to the GP. So thoughtful. Procedure went so well and all were so good and kind.  
2)Had 65-69yrs Covid vaccine at Craigavon. So well organised and its only day 2 of it being rolled out. Staff AND volunteers so kind and polite, I am proud to be in the UK in spite of all the negativity in the media. My nurse, Danielle, was lovely and chatty and they all must be exhausted. NHS Amazing.  
3) I forgot to commend the efficiency of my GP surgery for their help re thyroid blood tests, on-line prescriptions and general attitude when I need to use their services.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: uniformec48
title: All staff were very kind and helpful
body: I had my first AstraZeneca Vaccine at John Scott Health Centre. All the staff were very kind and helpful. You were given a number to be called and as I have wax in my ears and normally wear a hearing aid I explained to someone before I was called, and he told the person who would call me. The medic who gave me the vaccine did it well, and was very patient, as I had lots of layers on because I have Raynauds Disease.

author: atlascy49
title: Covid-19 vaccination
body: I received my first vaccination this afternoon at the South Lakes Leisure Centre, Craigavon. Everything was very well organised and the staff were friendly and helpful. There was no pain with the jab and I feel good -so far.

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Jimpy
title: Guts and Endoscopy
body: I just wanted to register the fact that during my visits to the Endoscopy department, my treatment was excellent and I am so proud and reassured that we've got a hospital of this quality available to us - and the staff of all ranks treated me so well, and with such friendliness and respect that I was totally reassured, even before the clinical side was started. So many thanks

readBy.name: Dorset County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust

author: DA2021
title: Calling for an ambulance
body:
My husband who suffers with anxiety, had injured a muscle, which caused get pain. but the first crew came out, early hours. John and Jamie. how wonderful they were, understanding, advising my husband all the time, and talking him through his problem. we felt awfully calling them, but they carried their job, with so much care. We then called again that week, Arnie and Nice. again treated us with respect and understanding. We thank them so much. We salute everyone working in very difficult times. also,the call operators trying to keep hound almost. thank to so much. Take care. Love an best wishes.  
[Unsure about 'Transport']

readBy.name: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

author: februaryjp56
title: Staff were on the ball
body: Went to John Scott Medical Centre, for the Vacc. It was very organised, clean, and the staff were on the ball with it all.

author: rainyg46
title: Great service
body: Great Service, she had two key workers who went out of the way to help.

author: uniformjq48
title: Really insightful
body: Really insightful, she was made aware that the drink and drugs were coping measures, up until then she was unaware on why she was doing it.

author: neptunekm64
title: Helped me
body: STARS is really good. Helped me in many ways.

author: indigomx84
title: Gave me tools
body: The services gave me the tools to work with going forwards

author: dancecy34
title: Covid Vaccine
body:
Well organised & treated with utmost respect. Felt in a safe environment at all times.  
100% put at ease. I could not fault any aspects

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: falconkf96
title: Help is out there
body: Still doesn't drink. If I needed more it was made aware the help that is out there

author: junepf77
title: Really helpful
body: Helped a lot, really open with the key worker who was really helpful and love all the help

author: matarxc86
title: Can't thank them enough
body: Brilliant, I was in a low place, at the time and really helped. S. T. A. R. S Team listened. Can't thank them enough

author: swingfr35
title: Couldn't feel it
body: Went for Covid Vaccination. Very quick, no waiting, well organised. Couldn't feel it unlike when I have flu vaccine

readBy.name: St. Andrews University ScotGEM Medical Students

author: dracocx47
title: The road to recovery
body:
I have used this service for many years now and have found it to be very helpful, sometimes it can be challenging and difficult, but that's to be expected. As the road to recovery has many twists and turns and isn't the easiest of journeys to take, but the most difficult things in life to overcome, can be the most rewarding and help you to grow and know yourself (and others) better.  
Recently my keyworker rewarded me by changing my prescriptions from daily supervised to twice a week pick up for my hard work and staying drug free for a long period of time.  
I have found that most of the services that are in place to supposedly help me, have continued to let me down and not helped me at all, but O. R. B has been the one service that has helped me and continue to do so. Which makes me feel better about myself and as long as you're honest and try your best to help yourself (even baby steps), its worthwhile.

author: geminifj47
title: The help they give me
body:
Well since I've been at 911 I have done quite a lot better than I have done in a long time, I have battled some very bad health issues, not very nice. The project is a life blood 4 many of the residents, I think I would prob b dead now with out the help they give me. I keep my house 2 geva + clean-ish!  
Speak 4 my sen, I don't want 2 leave my house, but 1 day I must.

author: scorpiusxx96
title: Covid 19 Vaccination
body:
i could not ask for anything better  
Nice smiley staff very helpful  
Thank you all very much  
Everything was good  
Made me feel great  
Nothing could have been better

author: Momo123
title: Appointment
body: I phoned the sexual health clinic to get tested. I wasn’t sure how things work these days with the pandemic so I phoned the clinic expecting to be told that I would have   to wait until the lockdown is over. I have been transferred to Susan who has been nothing but so helpful! I explained her everything She was so understanding and nice. I liked how everything is organised now You don’t have to leave the house, see anyone or face anyone Its so anonymous It’s a really good idea! Most of us is embarrassed to go and get checked as it’s not a pleasant and comfortable subject but Susan made me feel so relaxed. I think this is the way forward now Great work!

author: RelievedMum
title: Teen Rheumatology
body:
Today my daughter was signed off from treatment at the hospital's teen rheumatology department,  
Her care has been excellent, the staff (nurses, doctors, consultants) have all been incredibly professional and friendly, explaining things in good detail, answering all our questions. All excellent. Plus the quick identification and treatment made something that could have been very frightening into a well explained and supported journey. Thank you.

author: february2021
title: Covid-19 Vaccination
body:
Everything went well until the actual administration of the jab. I have to say this was the worst experience of all the jabs I've received. I travel, so have had the full range of vaccinations and regularly receive Vitamin B12 by injection.  
It felt more like being stabbed. They also turned down my request to take a selfie of the injection, which was refused in no uncertain terms. This would have been used as recommended by UNICEF and posted on Facebook.

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: cheetahps96
authorRole: a staff member posting for a patient/service user
title: A second family to me
body:
The new manager is a good manager  
Hill Hall Home are a second family to me. They helped me when I lost my mammy. I love Emily's chicken goujons and chips. I like getting my hair done with straighteners, out on bus and most of all the craic.  
(Staff wrote this for me I told them what to write)

readBy.name: South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust

author: Ssmhcdje36
title: Care in the community
body:
My husband died from terminal cancer recently. His wish was to stay at home for as long as possible.  
Throughout his illness he required lots of bloods to be taken and multiple medication reviews. Over the last few weeks he required daily end of life care.  
It was extremely challenging to look after him at home with COVID restrictions and Strathcarron Hospice being closed, palliative home visits were greatly curtailed and impatient care was not an option.  
Circumstances were difficult but the care and compassion shown and delivered by the Clackmannan community nursing team, the wider community nursing team at weekends, the Clackmannan GPs, Clackmannan Health Centre admin staff, the Out of Hours GPS and Clackmannan pharmacy was excellent.  
I can’t thank them enough.  
Thanks to all.

author: likeablehj63
title: Covid vaccination
body: Well organised, excellent staff & safe environment

readBy.name: Southern Health and Social Care Trust

author: festivityqc37
title: Vaccination
body: Very good experience at the vaccination hub. Felt well cared for even though the turnover was so high. Everyone from the security man on the door to the admin person on the desk to the doctor and nurses were so friendly and caring.

author: Mother55
title: Well cared for
body: My eldest child (aged 18), has been very well cared for on the ward by kind and professional staff

author: phoenixps84
title: Received COVID vaccination
body: The nurses couldn’t have been lovelier very reassuring and putting everyone at ease. Process was very quick. Each person had their own room where they met their nurse administrating the vaccination.
